Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2011 11:09AM jeanne46 wrote: Hi Louise, Have you started CMF yet?  I took CMF in 1992 when I was first diagnosed with stage 1 B/C. Do you know what your regimen will be? I did "Classic CMF" which meant a 5 minute IV push of Methotre. and 5FU on days 1 and 8, and oral cyto an on days 1-15, then two weeks off (28-day cycle).  My hair thinned a little; I was tired, and I dealt with the nausea effectively with sub-lingual ativan (.5 mg). The other anti-nausea drugs available then did not help me. It was not too bad. I also got decadron as a pre-med with each IV push. CMF is an old, tried and true drug.  It was the standard of care for adjuvant chemo for stage 1 disease then. I've heard that oncologists are starting to use it again. In fact, yesterday I had a long consultation with one of my medical oncologists and he wants me to try CMF again. The recent drug I tried knocked me out for almost 10 days.  So this a new option for me. He thinks there's a possibility that CMF may have kept me in remission from 1992 to Dec. 2005. Who knows?  Best of luck to you.  Let us know how you are doing.

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 12:02PM jeanne46 wrote: Just to offer a little information on CA 15-3 and 27-29,  Both are essentially the same test.  Some docs prefer one over the other.  I have never heard of someone getting tested for both.  In the metastatic setting, these tests CAN be helpful in monitoring disease progression/regression.  But only if the person tested has reliable scores.  If a score goes up one month, it can be due to variables other than cancer progression.  However, if the markers rise over a period of months, it is usually an indication of disease progression (as LuAnn mentioned, one is looking for a trend). The other fact to know is that it is difficult to compare same test results from different labs because each seems to have its own criterium for normal range.  The most reliable information on disease status is from test scans. Check with your oncologist if you want to know why she/he prefers one (15-3) over the other (27-29).  CTC (circulating tumor count) is a different test altogether.  It is not usually done on a regular basis. And while my disease showed progression on scans and TMs, my CTC was under 5.  Go figure.
Posts.Title: Question for the smart ladies on labs ibcspouse jeanne46

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 06:22PM - edited Jul 30, 2008 06:23PM by jeanne46 I was referring to tumor marker tests.  Either the 15-3 tumor marker is used or the 27-29 tumor marker is used.  "CA 27.29 is protein that is produced by the same gene (MUC1) as CA 15-3 and is used in the same way. It is newer than CA 15-3, but most doctors consider it essentially equivalent to CA 15-3. It can be used instead of CA 15-3, but you usually wouldn’t have both tests."  CA stands for "cancer antigen."

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 12:17PM - edited Apr 10, 2008 12:17PM by jeanne46 Debbie, The unfortunate, nasty little truth is that a lot of insurance companies put up walls to block claims unless they are pressed to do otherwise. Can't tell you the number of times I have spent (mostly "on-hold" - or being switched from department to department) contacting my insurance company about claims (and I have a PPO plus). It helps keep the blood from boiling!! Jeanne

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 05:58PM - edited Aug 17, 2008 09:31PM by jeanne46 Hi Bernice, There's at least two previous posts about Navelbine SEs - on this topic (Rec. and mets).  See if you can find them.. I have been on Navelbine for about 51/2 months.  When I started I got infused once every week for three weeks, then off week 4.  The infusions take about 15 minutes (then add time for CBC, and if you have a port, saline before and after).  I was told this was going to be an easy chemo - but found it difficult, especially at first.  Had stomach upset, felt achy and slightly feverish after day 2-3, and extremely fatigued.  I also experienced muscle weakness and am now in physical therapy to try to improve core muscle performance and balance.  I also needed Neulasta after third infusion of each cycle due to low WBC and occasionally Aranesp for low RBC, and the combination of the third infusion of the cycle and the Neulasta made me a very unhappy camper. Navelbine is notorious for causing constipation because it somehow slows the motility in the colon. If you've managed to miss that, then YEA!  I tried many different proton pump inhibitors (Protonix, Prilosec, Aciphex) also added in Zantac and occasionally chewed some TUMS. Sometimes you have to experiment a bit in order to find something that is effective in reducing the symptoms of acid stomach. I found my local pharmacist to be really helpful in this area. Lately I've been getting Navelbine every other week and managing to skip the neulasta.  My stomach issues have gotten much better and except for the first few days after each infusion, SEs are hardly apparent. Best of luck.  Hope your SEs get easier to tolerate.

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2009 09:31PM jeanne46 wrote: The tests are very controversial.  Most university/cancer centers docs do not use them at all.   However, if you want more info, PM me.  I had it done here in California, where there are at least two labs I know of.  They do need fresh tissue, packed a specific way from the surgery site, and shipped directly to the lab. Some insurance companies will cover the expense; others not.  It costs about $1-2K. There is another type of testing that is done on tissue to determine its characteristics and apply that information to determine what chemos it may be sensitive to.  Check out Caris Labs in ARizona.  There you can send either fresh or tissue that has been preserved in blocks from a previous biopsy.  When I had that done it was free, but my onc. had to order it.  I believe they were in a testing phase at the time.  Others may come along with more information.  This is all I know about personally. Best of luck to your wife and to you.

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2008 06:32PM - edited Oct 23, 2008 06:33PM by jeanne46 As long as you are getting the Lupron, Femara and Zometa I don't think it would hurt to add in the possibility of Avastin. You should be getting that for free, since it's in trial, and for a few months (you'd know by then) I don't think Avastin would be harmful and it could be helpful.  I've taken it twice. The worst thing was high blood pressure (after about 5 months) and I took meds to keep that under control. When I stopped the Avastin, blood pressure returned to normal.  The bloody nose is also pretty common, but not really a big deal. Having been in a trial before, you do get a lot of extra attention and are watched very closely. Just MHO. Best of luck.  Jeanne

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 10:33AM jeanne46 wrote: Well I suppose the thought is that theoretically, by removing one's boobs, that there is much less likelihood for a new cancer to develop in the breast.  Certainly that is what many, many ladies do when they find out that are BRCA1 or 2 positive - without presence of disease.   If breast cancer recurs (stage IV) it usually recurs in distant (as in not local - breast or lymph node) locations, such as bone, organs, etc. Cancer can travel not only via the lymph nodes, but through the blood system as well (a nasty little secret many women don't know). Many like me, who were initially node negative, had their cancer recur (stage IV). I'm sorry I don't have any statistics.  I highly recommend a skilled, informed onco or breast surgeon who can answer your questions with more knowledge and detail. Best of luck, Ms Javelina Breath.  (There are some current studies that are not so abysmal with regard to triple neg status.)  Have you gone on the triple neg boards?  Also there was a recent (June) discussion with Drs. Hope Rugo, John Link and someone else who specifically addressed the triple neg issue. I will try to find that thread for you. In the meantime, I don't think I will ever see a laundry shute without a picture of it in my head holding excised boobs! Jeanne

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2007 09:06AM jeanne46 wrote: Hi Ozzie, I just wanted to add that I too am confused about the various scans used. I've had a PET/CT, MRI and CT with and without contrast. Each seemed to show something different in terms of metastatic involvement. I asked the onc at one point why the difference, and his response was that each test often dx separate issues/areas. Huh? TMs are helpful but not always exact. Sometimes they will go up for a month or two while on a new treatment before going down. It's the overall trend you want to take note of. I do believe it does matter where the mets are and the size - how else can one measure if a treatment is working? Am glad you fired the clueless doc and found one who will "work" for you. Best of luck with the your next treatment. BTW have recently read that neurontin can sometimes be helpful for the hand/foot neuropathy from xeloda and that acupuncture has proved to be very helpful too. Wishing you well, Jeanne

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2008 10:59PM jeanne46 wrote: Plural effusions refer to a buildup of fluid in the pleura. It is not a disease in itself, but indicative of an underlying cause. See paragraph below. "Pleural effusion affects 1.3 million individuals each year. Approximate annual incidences of pleural effusions are based on major underlying disease processes, as follows: congestive heart failure, 500,000; bacterial pneumonia, 300,000 (uncomplicated, 270,000; complicated, 30,000); malignancy, 200,000; pulmonary embolus, 150,000; cirrhosis with ascites, 50,000; pancreatitis, 20,000; collagen vascular disease, 6,000; and tuberculosis, 2,500." Am hoping yours has nothing to do with cancer. Are you taking any drugs that may affect your heart? Jeanne

Posts.Content: jeanne46 wrote: Dear Sisters, I just returned from an inspiring and informative one-day conference on New Directions in Integrative Cancer Care It was held at the Commonweal grounds (see www.commonweal.org) in beautiful northern California (Bolinas). Commonweal alums and friends were invited to attend the first day of the three-day professional conference (attendees were from US and abroad) and we were privileged to hear from many presenters who spoke on the current direction and recent findings on integrative cancer care (translation: incorporating practices such as mind-body meditation, guided imagery, nutrition, herbal and nutritional supplements, exercise, spirituality exercise, chronotherapy, etc.) with traditional chemotherapy, surgery and/or radiation therapy. There were some giants there (Dr. Keith Block – out of Evanston IL – a pioneer of integrative psychobiological cancer therapies ( www.blockmd.com), Dr. Mark Renneker, (a pioneer in providing services as a medical consultant for people with serious illnesses, including cancer, who can thoroughly research every aspect of your particular case and can coordinate care or find practitioners who will), Dr. Jeremy Geffen (a medical oncologist and founder of Geffen Visions in Boulder, CO (www.geffenvisions.com), Dr.Dean Ornish, (a real pioneer in implementing an integrative approach to heart disease treatment and who has actually proven that by incorporating good nutrition, diet, exercise, stress reduction and support groups, heart disease can be reversed), and many other experts too numerous to name here.. The conference was lead by, Michael Lerner, co-founder of Commonweal and Smith Farm Center for Healing and the Arts and co-founder of both centers’ Cancer Help Programs and author of Choices in Healing (a highly recommended book for those of you interested in strongly academically-researched traditional and alternative approaches to treatment and healing. For those of us metsters with active disease, who daily tread the line between hope and hopelessness, this conference was a shot of hope and optimism and, for at least one day, “it was a very good day,” as Watson has often reminded us of our beloved Joanne’s remark. Integrative medicine is not a panacea. There are limitations in any kind of treatment and sometimes no matter what one does, disease progression continues. But, I think what really helped me, is realizing that there are options that we have (other than just another chemo) and things we can do to improve our quality, and maybe quantity, of life. Without taking up all the “paper” here, I just want to let you all know there is possibility. Alternative approaches include stress reduction, good nutrition, spirituality, herbal and nutritional supplementation designed to your specific need, exercise, acupuncture and others– all working together with traditional medical approaches to enhance a synergistic response for a positive outcome. The real issue and the one that needs the most attention right now, is how to get all these services available in one center, with all practitioners working together to devise an individualized plan AND (ta-da) covered by Medicare and the insurance companies. I have only touched the surface, so to speak, but I wanted to share this incredible event with you and am happy to answer more questions, should there be any. If your oncologist doesn’t think outside the box, there are places and professionals to turn to that might help the process along - if you want. Best wishes and blessings to all. Jeanne Dx 12/05, Stage IV, Grade 3 ER-/PR-Her2- YOU NEVER KNOW HOW STRONG YOU ARE UNTIL BEING STRONG IS THE ONLY OPTION YOU HAVE. -anonymous Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2010 11:08AM jeanne46 wrote: No one has mentioned Milk of Magnesia.  After using a few suppositories (no result) then drinking magnesium citrate (it helped uplug stuff!) I then started taking MOM daily.  My GP said to start off with a regular dose.  If that didn't work, double the dose until I had success.  Then adjust accordingly by the day.  The nice thing about MOM is that you can take it every day and it also helps with stomach problems associated with chemo.  Haven't experienced acid stomach in a long time. However, the taste could cause some to gag I suppose. I buy the cherry flavored. Sometimes it's tough to keep it down, but I have a handy glass of ice water nearby and start gulping that. Miralax likely does the same, without the stomach aid. I'm hard core (no pun intended!) with constipation issues, having experienced them long before cancer and chemo.  I've tried so many different combos - but this one seems to help. Panty liners or pads are definitely necessary!

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2008 11:11PM jeanne46 wrote: Navelbine is a push drug only if injected into arm vein- if using a port it takes about 15-20 minutes. At first I took Navelbine/Avastin once a week for three weeks, then one week off.  At the end of every cycle I had to get a Neulasta injection because my WCB was so low.  SEs included stomach issues (especially a lot of stomach acid), constipation, and then the joint and muscle pains from Neulasta and Navelbine. I also experienced some muscle loss and a spot of neurapathy on one foot (either that or it's something else).  I switched to every other week, and things have improved significantly. It's really easy to tolerate now.  Unfortunately, recent scans show it's no longer working. (Boo Hiss). You do not lose your hair and my onc never gave me any pre meds (no steroids!!).  Am sorry the Ixempra/Xeloda  didn't work - but some of your other options are not as harsh as the Ixempra (abraxane, avastin, navelbine). Best of luck. Am sending positive vibes and cyber hugs. Jeanne

Since I'll probably be on some form of chemo for the rest of my life I don't even consider that my eyesight will improve.  The few times I've had a break from chemo (for a month to 3 months) I did not notice a change in vision. I now have reading glasses, computer glasses and regular progressive glasses. Quite an assortment!!  I can't wear contacts due to my double vision issue.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2008 12:44PM - edited Mar 9, 2008 12:46PM by jeanne46 Hate to be the "damp rag" here - but after less than a year on zometa I developed "bisphosphonate-related osteo-necrosis of the jaw" in the upper area where I'd had a dental implant some five years (and pre-recurrance of cancer) previously. I had to stop taking zometa - but the area is still affected and the bone loss continues. "They" say that if bone mets are really bad, to continue with zometa anyway. ONJ will not kill you is the reasoning. I'm currently taking an inhalant for calcium that is not in the bisphosphonate family. I'm sure you all know this - but it does bear repeating: get any dental work you need BEFORE starting a bisphosphonate (zometa, aredia). Get your teeth cleaned frequently and use a soft toothbrush, floss daily and see your dentist at the first sign of any trouble. Good luck to all.

If you are getting some form of steroids in your pre-meds before taxol infusion, that may be enough to keep you "up" for at least a day. When steroids kept me awake right after infusion, I would take extra meds for sleep that night (I'm also not a good sleeper in the best of situations). Check with your onc about possibilities. As for nosebleeds, there are a few chemo drugs (notably avastin) that often cause nosebleeds. It's a good idea to let your oncologist know about them- either by leaving a message today or contacting the office tomorrow. (I'm back on avastin and think I will try Brenda's nasal irrigation suggestion.)

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2008 05:41AM - edited Apr 14, 2008 04:04AM by jeanne46 Sometimes you don't have a choice. I had 23 nodes removed from my left arm in 1992. From then on I only used my right arm for blood tests and blood pressure cuffs (which was the arm I had also received chemo in). Those veins are very small and always difficult to get a good "stick" from. Recently I had two lymph nodes removed from the right arm. Although part of the arm is still numb, I have to use it for blood pressure and blood tests if the person doing the test isn't qualified to access my port. I would try to avoid the arm (if you have only one) that has had the nodes removed. If you get a port, I would highly recommend the Bard power port, (or another version of same) that allows the MRI/PET/CT contrast dye to be put in the port (some of those procedures require the dyes to be put in with pressure. which the Bard port can accommodate). Before I had a power port I once had to have dye put into my ankle because they couldn't find a suitable vein in my right arm. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 12:44AM jeanne46 wrote: Snooch, When my first bout with BC and chemo put me into menopause over night - many years ago - I remember distinctly getting shortness of breath whenever I'd get a hotflash. Often my heart would start to beat more quickly, the shortness of breath would present, and the hot flash would erupt. As soon as the hotflash started to ebb, my breathing would return to normal.  There's something about vasoconstriction and hot flashes.  I still get hot flashes, but the "taking my breath away" is gone. Hot flashes can be brought on with exercise, too.   I'm not a physician and am in no way trying to diagnose your shortness of breath issue - but thought I'd share my experience with you. Best of luck figuring this out.

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 02:59AM - edited May 30, 2008 05:36AM by jeanne46 The problem with the study you cited is that it suggests that miso soup can PREVENT breast cancer, not prevent recurrence. Also, the Japanese tend to eat far less meat than we do, and less milk products as well. It may also be that those who ate more miso soup ate less meat and more vegetables. There was a study done a while ago in China (The Cancer Project). Again, for groups that ate very little or no meat and no dairy (in other words a diet rich in vegetables) the incidence of breast cancer was far less than in the cities where diets were richer in animal products. Supposedly, if you are ER+ soy is more of an issue (it has estrogenic qualities) than if one is ER-. But I don't think the jury is out on that subject. If you like miso soup, and have no problems with sodium and make sure there is no MSG in the soup, go for it. I especially like miso soup on cold days. But you can also include lots of dark leafy green veggies in your diet, BBQ tofu (buy the firm kind and be sure to marinate first) instead of beef or make your own soup rich in veggies with some tofu added and have control over how much salt or sodium to add. (BTW: sea salt is much better for you than regular salt because of the minerals in the sea salt.) Nothing is ever as easy as it seems! Jeanne

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 10:51PM jeanne46 wrote: I really understand what you're going through and remember how difficult it was for me to grasp the enormity of the concept of incurable disease when my cancer first recurred. It was my worst nightmare come true. And the first few times I had scans I even took some valium, which the radiologist gave me, just so I could lie still. But one of these days you will find that you have overcome the initial shock and then, hopefully, you will find ways to live each day that gives you some meaning and happiness. It's not easy. And it helps to keep in contact with people who are going through similar experiences as you are. Eventually I realized that I had no other choice than to try to live each day as stress-free as possible and not waste valuable time on cancer. Like, "today's just not a good day for cancer!" You will get through this. Don't beat yourself up because of your reaction. Everyone experiences similar feelings. Your body hasn't betrayed you - cancer has. It is your body that will help you destroy the cancer cells with the help of chemo. Treat your body well and make sure it gets plenty of rest, good nutrition, exercise, laughter, and lots of hugs. Sending a virtual hug your way - along with best wishes for some good days ahead. Jeanne

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2009 10:06AM jeanne46 wrote: I have no experience with either fake or tattooed eyebrows, but if I could, I would definitely go the tattoo route.  If you decide to do that, make sure you go to a professional who has a good track record with low complications. Infections are possible, and that would be bad news. I don't have many eyebrow hairs (they are noticeable, but sparse); it seems that after my hair returned from Abraxane treatment, my eyebrows didn't grow back as much (nor my eyelashes).  I use a powder eyebrow liner - and usually it managers to stay on well all day.  I have also used a pencil.  You might go to a make-up counter and ask about long lasting eyebrow liners. For everyday eyelash "look" try lining the top of your eyelid, close to the lash line, with a gel liner. It helps give the look of eyelashes and for me, they last longer than a pencil. Soem of these tricks I learned in an American Cancer Society "Look Good Feel Good" class. They also hand out free make-up.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 04:29PM jeanne46 wrote: Brenda, My onc suspected that I had SVC syndrome - but it turned out to be a DVT in the vena cava caused by my port.  The syndrome issue usually means there is something pressing on the outside of the vein to cause blockage.  After unsuccessfully trying anti-coagulants, I had the port removed.  Beside the DVT I also had narrowing of the vena cava below the DVT due, they believe, to scar tissue caused from the port. The problem with pic lines or passport ports (in arm) is that the tubing still goes through the vena cava.  It's a dilemma.  Hopefully you will do well on the xeloda and get any other IV through your arm. I've been squeezing a soft rubber ball 4-5 times a day to try and strengthen my arm veins. It doesn't sound like you had any symptoms.  I had pressure along each side of my neck and my head felt like it was upside down. Perhaps the Xeloda will solve all these problems.  Am keeping my fingers crossed for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 11:29PM jeanne46 wrote: So very sorry to hear about your possible recurrence. However, it sounds like there is some question as to why the nodes showed up hot. Did they get enough tissue from the biopsy of the abdominal nodes? Usually breast cancer cells show up as breast cancer cells, wherever the spots are. There is a possibility, from what you report, that this is something else. I'm not qualified to hazard a guess, but unless the tissue has been identified as cancer for sure, there's always the chance it is benign. It sounds like your oncologist is being thorough in ordering a comparison from your slides of '06 to your recent biopsy. Before you jump ahead of yourself (I know it's really hard NOT to do), you need to find out what this tissue is and what the characteristics, if it is breast cancer, are. Sometimes the ER/PR changes, etc. You ask good questions about the PET scan. Since you haven't had one before, it's possible these "hot" nodes have been there for a while. There are other tests that can sometimes be used to compare - like CT of abdomen, whole body bone scan, and or PET/CT. Hang in there. This is the worst time of all. Waiting, not knowing, expecting the worst, etc. Your bc sisters here will be pulling for you. Drop in any time to share thoughts, ask questions, or whatever you need. I'm sure there will be lots more responses with lots of good understanding and wisdom. Gentle hugs, Jeanne Best wishes to you.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2007 12:04PM jeanne46 wrote: After a year and a half my first port developed red lines along the tube coming out of the port itself (I believe it was a vaxcel titanium model). I was treated with antibiotics and the port was also checked for leakage. Nothing showed up. I was on avastin and abraxane (paclitaxel) at the time. When I switched to oral meds (unrelated to the port!) I had the port removed. A few months later, and back on chemo infusions, I had a new port inserted (a Bard power port) on the same side of my chest, but to the left of the location of the previous port. So far I've had no problems and no red lines. My first port was put in by a radiologist and he didn't do a very pretty job. The second one was implanted by a wonderful surgeon who made it look less noticeable and placed the tube UNDER my clavicle. I would only have an experienced surgeon do that procedure again if I needed it. I have had friends whose first port insertions got infected and required removal and reinsertion of a new one. You should probably take a break from the avastin to give your body some time to heal, if that's what you choose. There's something called vasculitis that can occur with port tubes. What does your onc or surgeon say? I haven't had any experience with PICC lines but that also sounds like an option, especially if you and your onc. decide it's more important for you to remain on avastin. Best of luck to you, whatever you decide.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 05:32PM jeanne46 wrote: My surgeon at Scripps Memorial in La Jolla inserted my Bard power port. It can be done by a surgeon or an interventional radiologist. I've had two, inserted by both, and highly recommend the surgeon route. Make sure they show you where the incision will be - and that it won't rub at the top or side of your bra. But (and there's always a BUT it seems) I've had some problems getting the qualified personnel to access my port for scans. First of all, they need a special needle for the port - and only nurses can access it. It must be flushed out, the dye inserted, then flushed out again. When you schedule a scan, be sure to tell the personnel that you want the dye inserted through your port and therefore need an interventional nurse. Sometimes you have to be insistent. The last time I had surgery, I wanted them to use my port instead of my veins because they are so difficult to find, and at first everyone said, "NO." But in the end, the anesthesiologist agreed to do it. Good luck. If you want any more info, just PM me.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 12:22AM - edited Jun 26, 2008 12:22AM by jeanne46  How was your bone biopsy done?  Sometimes bone biopsies can be misleading - especially if the bone tissue is dried out first. Sometimes the biopsies are not read correctly.  I might suggest sending your biopsy sample to a third lab for confirmation.  Also, tumor markers can bounce around and when they dropped to 50 that may have been a result of the initial round of rads or just an anomaly.  It does sound like it's time to find a new onc.  One who will be around and one with whom you have more trust. Best of luck. Jeanne

Someone on these boards described the scan waiting as "scanic attacks." I can identify with that! Good luck to you. I hope you have the best possible outcome.

Posts.Content: jeanne46 wrote: Am currently showing symptoms of myopathy (muscle weakening). Have any of you out there had this as a side effect with chemotherapy? I took avastin and abraxane for almost 11 months without any problems. Then tried a few hormonals that didn't work. Then was part of a clinical trial involving a non-chemo drug. Am now taking navelbine and avastin and suddenly my leg muscles (especially the upper back thighs) are weaker. On my right side, it's difficult to go upstairs without really using the rail for support. So far, at least, I have not developed any neuropathy. My oncologist said it's a side effect and probably reversible when I stop the medication (which is working presently so I hope I don't have to stop it any time soon). I feel like an old lady and am starting to walk like one, too. I do occasionally freak out that I'm starting to develop some other disease. Would love to hear from anyone who's experienced this. And if there is anything I can do to lessen the effects????? Jeanne Dx 12/05, Stage IV, Grade 3 ER-/PR-Her2- YOU NEVER KNOW HOW STRONG YOU ARE UNTIL BEING STRONG IS THE ONLY OPTION YOU HAVE. -anonymous Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2007 09:05AM jeanne46 wrote: Yes, ER/PR status can transform from positive to negative. Her2 status doesn't change because it has to do with a gene everexpression. However, sometimes the first test for HER/2 status might not have been accurate. According to my onc. ER/PR doesn't change from negative to positive. In my case my first dx was ER/PR+. When my cancer recurred over 13 years later, it was ER/PR - Just because the bone mets have progressed doesn't necessarily mean that you are no longer ER/PR+ It may mean that those meds are no longer effective. Cancer cells are tricky little buggers and just when you think you've found a way to beat them, they find a way to beat the treatment. Good luck to you! jeanne

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2007 01:42AM - edited Dec 30, 2007 01:43AM by jeanne46 So sorry to hear of your news - but be assured, there are many ladies with bone mets who are doing very well. Once the bone has been biopsied, and the pathologists can define the ER/PR/HER2 status, you may be able to start on something like hormonals and herceptin, and a bisphosphonate for bone health. The hardest part is waiting to get your plan in place. I think I lost 5 lbs. overnight when I first found out. But it does get easier and once you get started, life will look a little more normal. It's been two years for me (I found out right before Christmas in '05) since my bc recurred and I'm still doing regular stuff and those 5 lbs I lost have come back threefold! There are lots of inspiring stories on this board. The ladies here are truly caring and full of love and empathy. Best of luck to you and keep in touch. Sending gentle hugs and positive thoughts.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2010 02:53PM jeanne46 wrote: I know you feel really crappy about this - but here are a few things you may not realize: 1) Not everyone loses their hair on Abraxane - it will definitely thin.  I did lose mine, but it started growing back while I was still on it. 2)  I was lucky and able to handle the Abraxane pretty well.  The Avastin caused some nosebleeds, runny eyes, runny nose - but I still managed to go about an almost normal day (except for maybe the day after). 3)  Not all chemos leave you bald.  I'm going on my 8th or 9th chemo tomorrow and it will only be the second time I will lose my hair.  There's no way about it.  Chemo sucks. Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 12:31PM jeanne46 wrote: Some people do really well on Xeloda; others can have a more difficult time.  I guess it's like a lot of chemos.  I tried it for three months (didn't work for me) and my protocol was on two weeks, off a week.  If you start to have a difficult time I know your dose can be lowered, and I've heard of many ladies doing Xeloda one week on, one week off.  Keeping your hands and feet well creamed is really helpful for the hand and foot redness that can occur. During the day I used Udder Cream (can be found at CVS or Walmart I think) and at night I used Bag Balm (same stores have that, too) and used light cotton gloves and socks to keep the greasiness on my skin and not on my sheets! A brand called Gold Bond also has a very strong cream - and Eucerin makes some too.  Try a few samples and see which ones feel best on your skin.  Best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 03:46PM jeanne46 wrote: Normally the tissue samples are put in blocks and kept at the lab they are initially sent to. Request that the onc have the samples tested for HER/2 status.  My initial BC recurrence was confirmed with a resected rib sample. Or you might want the samples sent to another lab (check with your first oncologist for recommendation). I personally know of a well-respected lab that made a huge mistake that was caught when the patient had the sample tested at another center, then reconfirmed at the first lab.  Unless there's an issue of not getting enough bone to study the pathology, there should be no reason that the pathologist can't tell you if it's breast cancer or not. So sorry you are dealing with all this on top of the dx.  Keep us informed.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 07:34PM jeanne46 wrote: Hydrate, hydrate, hydrate.  I'm on low-dose adriamycin once a week x 3 and one week off. I feel lousy on days 1-3 afterward each week.  I can't imagine full strength AT once every 3 weeks. Make sure (due to adria) you get some really good anti-nausea meds (like emend).  If your doc's office is close by see if you can arrange for IV hydration the next day. My doc lives an hour and a half away, so the nurses leave the needle in my arm (all wrapped up), and my husband hooks me up the next day at home with a bag of saline that the kindly nurses give us, along with the tubing. However, every three weeks for 12 weeks is 4 times??  That countdown should help get you through.  Best of luck that it obliterates all those nasty tumahs. And did I say hydrate? If you can tolerate Biotene mouthwash, it's good to use to rinse your mouth out frequently and guard against mouth sores - or you can try rinsing with salt water instead.  Brush frequently too.

Posts.Content: jeanne46 wrote: 1.  If you take anti-depression meds, for heaven's sake do not forget to take them! 2.  When the plumber says he's going to turn off your water for three hours, pee BEFORE he does it. 3.  When driving into the ticket booth at the hospital/medical center, DO NOT drive too close to the left side.  You will smash your (electric, in my case) left-side rear-view mirror.  4.  When you bop on in the radiation center for your quick set of x-rays in anticipation for the rads which are scheduled to begin on Monday, expect them to tell you the machine is not working and please come back in an hour. 5.  When you return in one hour, expect them to tell you that your rad onc has decided that if the films are okay you're gonna' start today! Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 05:41PM jeanne46 wrote: Thanks for the correction that metronomic therapy does not necessarily involve only the two drugs I mentioned above.  When I asked my onc about the therapy, he seemed to think it was used more as an anti-angiogenisis treatment, rather than as a cytoxic treatment.  Robin, perhaps when you have a chance to talk with Dr. Winer you could ask him??? Rich,  there is a lot of controversy with the chemosensitivity assay.  I had it done by the Weisenthal lab and all but two drugs came back "Resistant." You can imagine how devastated I was.  However I recently was on a drug that my assay showed resistance to,  but which I had some good response.  My onc seems to feel that molecular profiling (currently in experimental phase by CARIS/MPI in Arizona) offers better information because it offers  an immunohistochemical analysis of patient tissue.  The chemosensitivity assay test can be helpful to some.  I've spoken with Dr. Weisenthal and met with Dr. Nagourney.  But most cancer center docs do not have much faith in the tests.  No need to respond; I know there are arguments on either side.  Just not  black and white. And there are variables (besides high cost) depending on the amount of tissue available and if solid tissue can be resected and how long ago the assay was done. There is an oncologist outside of Chicago (in Evanston) - Dr. Richard Bloch who does timed therapy with his patients and claims to have gotten very good results.  I've seen him speak and he's quite dynamic.  He also practices integrative therapy (using nutrition, supplements, exercise, emotional therapy, yoga) to compliment the chemo protocol. Jeanne

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2008 12:52AM jeanne46 wrote: I took tamoxifen for five years (recommended amount) and had no side effects other than hot flashes - but those may also have been tied into the chemo I took that put me into menopause. Tamoxifen can be a life saving drug if your Mom's cancer is ER/PR+ - that is, fueled by estrogen. There are other types of anti-estrogen drugs that your Mom can discuss with her oncologist - but if your Mom is followed closely while on the tamoxifen, she should do just fine. Perhaps your Dad could join your Mom at her next appointment and have his questions about tamoxifen answered. Good luck to her and to all of you. You are a very caring daughter and am glad to found our forum. Let us know how things turn out.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2009 02:08AM jeanne46 wrote: Tumor markers are generally only used as a measure of how a treatment is working in the metastatic setting.  Not all people with Stage IV disease show increased tumor marker numbers; some oncologists don't even use TMs.  Since your sister's makers have gone down to 3500 and since she also feels better, it's a good sign that her chemo treatment was working.  Because they have stayed at the same number, it's a good idea that her oncologist is scanning again.  Scans really give the most definitive picture of what's going on. I'm sure your sister's diagnosis has been devastating; give her as much support and love as you can.  And make sure to get some support for yourself, too.  This is not an easy journey.

Posts.Title: abcess tooth kbugmom KiminJax

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 05:13PM jeanne46 wrote: Don't know your situation other than you appear to be ER/PR + What's your Her/2 status? I took abraxane with avastin for almost 9 months until it stopped working. I had minimal side effects, other than hair loss and a metallic taste in my mouth. The avastin caused some nosebleeds, and runny eyes and nose and high blood pressure that returned to normal when I quit taking it. Abraxane has the advantage of not requiring pre-med with steroid because it is suspended in nano-particles that make it much easier for your body to accept. There are lots of other chemo drugs out there - the platinums [cisplatin, carboplatin], gemcitabine [gemzar], CMF [an old cocktail that seems to be used occasionally today], cyto- somethings - sorry that's my chemo brain today, etc. I think your onc needs an attitude adjustment and perhaps some more information - or perhaps you could find a more compassionate and caring onc. Just a thought. Good luck to you - and don't let anyone quit for you. That's your decision.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2010 04:21PM jeanne46 wrote: This morning I had the appointment with the wig expert lady.  She is a colon cancer survivor and pretty much lost her hair permanently, so she wears wigs daily.  Since she's in the biz, I'm sure she has plenty to chose from.  She was a doll.  Kept calling me "Precious" and hugging me.  She took one look at my human hair wig and said she will have to thin,thin, thin it (YES!).  But I was very encouraged when she said it was a good wig and that I didn't overpay. She also looked at my scalp and said the skin was still white which meant it would be few more days until it all falls out. Apparently the scalp skin turns pink/red when the hair really falls out.) I'm hoping I can hang onto this baseball cap look for a few more days. She also gave me an eyebrow hint.  After you brush on your eyebrows with powder, take a #2 sharpened pencil and draw little hairs in the powder. You might need to wet the pencil a little.  Her eyebrows looked fabulous. So the sun DID come out today! I know there are many more important things to worry about with cancer mets - but it's taken me a while to work through this bald head thing again. Thanks to all of you for your insightful comments, suggestions and empathy. This is the only place I could go and know you would "get it."

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 02:57PM jeanne46 wrote: I just had my port replaced due to other reasons. But the surgeon who inserted the new one put in a Bard port because it can take the pressured CT contrast dye - with a special needle. You need to have that needle for pressure IV. Nurses are trained not only to access ports, but to flush as well (which is really imortant with a port). I am also a hard stick, and last time (pre-Bard) I had my CT scans done, and after being stuck 4 times, I finally got really pushy and requested an "intervention nurse." Most centers that do CTs (mine happened to be at a hospital) have intervention nurses for just that reason. She was able to find a vein in one stick. I have to have blood tests weekly and have finally decided that I will only be stuck by one particular phlebotomist. You really have to stand up for yourself or the risk of getting multiple sticks is constant. The other thing I found to be helpful is to use a heating pad or some other warm device to help plump the veins beforehand. However, I also agree, that sometimes it is a crap shoot. Once at the imaging center where I get PET/CT scans, even the doc couldn't find a vein. They finally went into my ankle - and I understand that is risky for blood clot complications. It seems that for us "hard sticks" there should be specially trained nurses or techs who can get "blood from a turnip."

Posts.Content: jeanne46 wrote: Took out the VERY expensive human hair wig I bought last December when I had healthy, very brown hair.  For some reason the weekly low-dose adriamycin did not cause my hair to fall out as I was assured it would; it just thinned.  Then about 4 months ago I had to stop adria for a while to have an excisional biopsy, following a not-so-good-scan.  Onc and I decided to go back on the adria and give it a few more months.  By then, my hair was thinning out more. greying, and losing color- looking very unhealthy. It's been 6-8 weeks since I've been off adriamycin and my hair has continued to fall out and look crappy. So today I took out out the wig because now my hair is really falling out (the Day 14 rule) from taxotere, and OMG. The hair is so much darker than my hair color now, (at the time it seemed that we even went outside to match hair color when I bought the wig). When I tried it on this morning, I looked like I was wearing a very dark MOP HEAD.  Geeesh.  I took it to the gal who sold it to me and she washed it and then restyled it and tried to thin it.  But now, everyone I see will immediately know I'm wearing a wig (mostly I'm referring to the people I do NOT want knowing about my cancer) - even my friends will need some getting used to it. IT"S NOT ME! If you didn't know me, it would probably look okay - just a lot more hair than I ever had - but definitely more natural than some of the "styled" synthetic wigs. I would have gone that route but the last time I lost my hair, the synthetic wigs itched so badly that I was uncomfortable most of the year I wore one. The other issue is that I have this ominous feeling that I will be bald from now on - and the idea of being bald in a hospital bed just makes me cringe. Somewhere between vanity and overwhelming sadness about my mets progression I have fixated on the "look."  It's so much easier to float down DeNile with a full head of hair (or even thinned crummy hair). I worry about my husband and my kids. It will be hard to look into their eyes and see their sadness too. I'm just really down at the moment - trying to find some ladder rungs to hitch myself up on.  I know life is not fair or none of us would have cancer. But the double whammy of weight gain, unhealthy skin, and no hair just adds another dimension of unfairness to our being. BOO HISS. Thanks for letting me rant. The sun will come out tomorrow, I think.  Dx 12/05, Stage IV, Grade 3 ER-/PR-Her2- YOU NEVER KNOW HOW STRONG YOU ARE UNTIL BEING STRONG IS THE ONLY OPTION YOU HAVE. -anonymous Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2008 08:17PM - edited Mar 30, 2008 08:29PM by jeanne46 I was on zometa less than a year when I developed ONJ - not the typical open wound on the bottom jaw, but in the gum area that previously had a dental implant inserted (years before I started the zometa). The result is bone loss and constant irritation - no pain - and my oral surgeon said that eventually the implant will fall out, and most likely the tooth next to it - whose root is also affected. Regular cleanings and filling cavities should not be a problem. Root canal, tooth extraction, and trauma to the tooth or surrounding tissue should cause concern while on a bisphosphonate. I have heard that there are some new protocols now giving IV bisphosphonates (aredia or zometa) every three months instead of monthly. All this should be discussed with your oncologist, of course, and as someone else mentioned, I do not know if this makes a difference in ONJ risk. I think ONJ has been under-reported, as does my regular dentist. Although I have seen an oral surgeon familiar with ONJ and he is certain I have ONJ, no one can identify it as such with 100% accuracy (to do so would involve invasive tests that could make the condition worse). Some dentists manage it with clondomycin (an antibiotic) and may not always report it to the drug companies for various reasons, even if there are open wounds that are more clearly seen as ONJ. Sorry to be the spoiler here, but thought you should know the other side.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2010 03:14PM jeanne46 wrote: All IV bisphosphonates have a very long half life (they stay in your body for a long time).  I don't know about the oral ones - but ALL can cause ONJ.  When I first started taking zometa in February of '06 no one told me to see a dentist first.  However, having no dental work needed on the horizon and a dental implant that was done 3-4 years previous to my cancer recurrence, I thought all would be fine.  Not so. After a year I started regularly bleeding from the gum surrounding the implanted tooth.  Many anti-biotics and dx followed until we realized it was ONJ. It occured in the maxilla (top jaw) which is rare.  It usually presents in the mandilla or lower jaw and often as an open sore that exposes bone.  In my case I lost two teeth.  It doesn't seem to be affecting any other area right now.  If you need any dental work, definitely do it now - especially any invasive work.  And do try to see a dentist or oral surgeon who is familiar with ONJ.  It might be a good idea to have a panorama x-ray as a baseline before you begin bisphosphonate therapy. That said, remember that ONJ is still pretty uncommon.  Many many ladies takes bisphosphonates with no problem at all.  As with all chemo and other drugs, there's always a risk. It's a decision we all make as to which risk we choose!

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2009 08:22PM jeanne46 wrote: I did A/A when I was first dx with mets (after three failed cycles on Xeloda).  It worked really well for me and I stayed on that protocol for about 10-11 months.  I lost my hair, but it did start growing back while I was still on the chemo - just very thin and sparse.  I was lucky and did not have any problems with peripheral neurapathy.  The Avastin caused my eyes to water all the time and my nose was constantly running.  I should have bought stock in Kleeneex.  Occasionally I had a bloody nose.  I managed to stay on a pretty normal schedule - planning any trips or special events during the two weeks off (there are two weeks between day 15 and day 1 of next cycle). I didn't need premeds nor anti nausea meds.  Occasionally I took an ativan for stomach upset. I hope it works for all of you and that you find it doable enough without bad SEs.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 11:23AM jeanne46 wrote: Pee - are you on anything else beside Avastin (and now Aredia)?  Sorry I don't remember from your previous posts.  Aredia is similar to Zometa (both are bisphosphonates).  Aredia is pamidronic disodium and Zometa is zolendronic acid.  Both are used for same purpose and both can cause flu-like symptoms and joint/bone ache. Personally I was quite lucky and didn't suffer any side effects from the IV. Make sure you have all dental work done (if necessary) before starting the Aredia and let your dentist know you are on Aredia..  Also brush frequently with a soft toothbrush and use dental floss to keep teeth and gums as clean as possible.  One nasty side effect of bisphosphonates (only occurs to a small minority of which I'm a unhappy member) is osteonecrosis of the jaw. Sorry about the progression - but rest assured there's lots of drugs in the chemo arsenal and hopefully this new combo will work wonders. Don't worry about the pity party - we all have them. I think of them as a sort of catharsis in order to move on. Hugs.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 08:42AM jeanne46 wrote: Hi Janmarie, I was on avastin and abraxane for almost a year. My protocol was three weeks on, one week off. Except for losing my hair, some metallic taste in my mouth, some nose bleeds and runny nose and eyes (nothing exceptional and nothing that got in the way of leading a very normal life) the SE's were completely doable. The first time I got it they also gave me kytril for nausea, but it gave me a headache. The next and all ensuing infusions I didn't take any anti-emetics. It's important to remember that each of us reacts differently to these poisons, but it seems that when taken on a weekly basis, A&A are much easier to tolerate than once every three weeks. Best of luck to you - hope this treatment really knocks the socks out of the cancer!

If these drugs don't work for you, then I assume metronomic therapy is not an option.   Vivo - I understand your concerns and frustration. I just had scans on Monday and today the chemo nurse called to tell me that the onc wants to talk to me tomorrow about the scan, but hold off on the chemo.  Now, what do you think that means?  Crap.  Am currently on my 7th cocktail (in December I reached the 4-year mark) and now I'm really scared about what lies ahead. So, I guess the best we can do is move on and keep hoping.  There's a 5-part article running in the New York Times about an oncologist/researcher who started a clinical trial with patients in late stage melanoma.  One was so close to death they almost didn't include him in the trial. And within weeks all of the patients started to improve and their tumors shrunk dramatically - to the point that some appeared to be without disease.  Perhaps a new drug awaits us too - and could be just around the corner.  It's important to keep hope alive.

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2008 09:51PM jeanne46 wrote: Sorry you had to join us here.  But there are a lot of us LIVING with cancer and some doing exceedingly well. First of all, if your cancer is in bone only, that's a good thing.  Mets to bone is rarely life-threatening. Often patients are treated with AIs (like Femara or Arimidex) or Faslodex along with an IV bisphosphonate (like Zometa).   My onc only radiates if there is pain or some other compelling reason (location is near a vital nerve, etc.). I have not heard of a 4-month infusion of taxotere.  But for your peace of mind, and your family's, I would suggest a second opinion ASAP (before you begin any treatment) and also find an oncologist who is much more optimistic and compassionate.  Since you are ER/PR+ there is every possibility that you can do well on AIs for a long time. LuAnn will come along shortly and tell you her story.  She has bone only mets as well, and has only done AIs, faslodex and zometa. Best of luck to you.  Hang in there.  You have every reason for hope. Jeanne

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2010 02:33PM jeanne46 wrote: Since your Mom's markers have been steadily increasing, there is a good chance it could mean progression. There are many disagreements about the validity of tumor marker tests, but they are often used to track chemo protocols on Stage IV patients. With some, no matter how much tumor load they have, the tumor markers remain in normal boundaries. With others, tumor markers are more responsive to what is actually going on. Definitely discuss this with your Mom's onc if she agrees.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 12:03AM jeanne46 wrote: Denise,  Press your oncologist's office to call the insurance company and request approval again for the PET/CT. Often the insurance companies will push back unless questioned.  You can also call the company and ask a service representative what you should do to get the PET/CT approved (sometimes "they" can actually be helpful). Don't give up.  I know it sucks to have to fight for something you need - but that's another road we don't need to go down right now!   CT's and bone scans are pretty accurate for what they picture.  Especially if you have bone mets, whole body bone scans can pinpoint areas of activity.  However, it would be best if the radiologist had the same type of films to compare from the last set of scans. While whole body bone scans do cover most of the body (including arms and legs) CTs are specific to the area being scanned (i.e., chest, abdomen, pelvis). Gentle hugs, Jeanne

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 01:00AM jeanne46 wrote: Recurrence refers to cancer that has come back. It can come back locally, regionally, or it can be metastatic. Metastatic means that the cancer has traveled to distant parts of the body (lymph nodes, bones, organs, etc.). Someone who is initially dx with breast cancer that has spread to lymph nodes is not considered metastatic.

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 06:25PM jeanne46 wrote: I posted a question like this a long while ago.  The first two years after my recurrence, the only instructions I was given at the radiology facility I was going to, was to be sure to fast for 6 hours before the test and drink lots of water.  (all of these scans were actually PET/CTs).  Then I swtiched to another lab and was told not to exercise the day before, not to chew gum the day before and to eat a high protein, low carb diet as well.  No sodas, no caffeine.  Some vegetables were okay as long as they didn't have many carbs in a serving. Hard cheese was okay.  Lots of water was also suggested. I was told this gives the radiologists a better scan to read. I don't know how much difference it makes.  For sure it helps to go to the same facility or to have your scan read by the same radiologists each time. I figured it wouldn't hurt to prep the more stringent way and if that produced a more reliable scan, then it was worth it.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 12:33AM jeanne46 wrote: The MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition scan) is done in nuclear med and involves an injection of your own red blood cells (that's first been extracted and mixed with some radioactive dye).  An echocardiogram is an ultrasound. They both look for left ventricular ejection fraction - a marker for heart disease. Some docs think that the MUGA is more definitive, but the echo does not involve any radioactive exposure.   As for Adria and Cytoxan - I'm sure that's a good option.  However, it seems that a lot of Stage IV ladies are often treated first with a taxol and avastin.  If you can, maybe it would be a good idea to get a second opinion.  There are also other anti-hormonals such as faslodex and aromasin that might also work for you. What is your HER/2 status? Best of luck to you. I'm sure whatever you choose you will be in good hands and I hope you get another nice long dance with NED (no evidence of disease)!

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 12:20AM jeanne46 wrote: It's definitely a good idea to get this checked out. However......I had a really bad attack of sciatica in the middle of a chemo treatment and the doc sent me for an MRI. Results confirmed just sciatica - so he sent me to an orthopedist who recommended physical therapy and gave me some anti-inflammatory meds. Sciatica involves a pinched nerve and perhaps your particular area gets compression when you are lying down. Mine was okay when lying down, just really painful when I stood up and or walked around. The pain ran all the way down my leg and across my foot from the outside to my big toe. I was quite lucky that it didn't last too long. While you made a good decision to see your doc, bone pain is not always associated with bone mets. When my bone mets were discovered, I was pretty much asymptomatic. Let us know how you are doing. Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 03:51PM jeanne46 wrote: I've been on chemo for over the last four years, with a few breathers in between, either waiting for test results, surgery or some other problems.  And I can tell you, that when I've been off chemo more than three weeks, I'm always amazed how good I feel.  Of course then I think the cancer has gone away. "Sorry," says onc, "it's because you're not on chemo!!" While I was on Navelbine a year or more ago, I had real issues with my core muscles and couldn't even do one girlie pushup.  My legs were weak and my balance was off.  I started physical therapy (and eventually got my chemo infusion schedule changed) and my strength returned.  Maybe not the same as before I was dx with mets, but enough to carry on a normal-style.  I suspect your lack of energy is directly related to the chemo.  Ask your onc to test your iron levels.  Also, getting Neulasta or Aranesp (for red cell counts) is usually determined by the simple blood test that your onc likely does each time you go in for chemo. Ritalin is used primarily for adolescent ADHD, and in adults has the effect of an "upper."  I imagine for some it's really helpful. But check with your onc about the iron, and the white and red cell counts first. Your level of fatigue doesn't sound as worrisome as someone who might not be able to function at all (can't get off the couch; can't stop sleeping...).  But since you are used to much more activity, I understand your concern.   Perhaps you could start at a lower outdoor pace and work up to more mileage.  If .3 mile is all you can do right now, then do that for a week.  Then see if you can push it up higher. Best of luck.  I hope the Cisplatin takes you to a long dance with Ned!

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 02:24AM - edited Jun 5, 2008 02:25AM by jeanne46 You know, losing one's happy place now and then just happens. We're told to keep up a cheery face, congratulated that we are so brave and courageous, implored to maintain a positive attitude because that can affect our outcome; we try to protect our family, close friends and hide our condition from fellow workers or acquaintances because we don't want to be pitied. (Do you think your message hit a chord with me??) Well, some days are just crappy. Some days we just don't feel like being all those wonderful, peppy things. So I say - call it a pity party, or missing our happy place, or just feeling off-game - whatever - it's a bad day and sometimes not worth the struggle to fight. My frequent answer is to go to bed, pull up the covers and watch something really idiotic on TV. Others may choose taking a walk, working on a project or shopping. Whatever works. I think we need to give ourselves a break, a chance to feel sad, to feel frustrated, to feel out of sorts, to be sick and tired of being filled up with chemos and drugs and side effects and ordinary (of course, when you have cancer NOTHING is ordinary!) aches and pains This is another side of our life, too. Don't be hard on yourself. You'll get your game back. Just nurture yourself, forgive yourself, hug yourself and let others do the same for you. And I also vote with LuAnn. Anti-depressants can be really helpful! Not all drugs make us feel bad. Hugs, Jeanne

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 02:50PM jeanne46 wrote: Brenda, I've had two ports since mets DX. First one developed a problem after a 1 1/2. Both times it was no big deal. However, with that being said, I highly recommend that you have a surgeon put in the port and ask them to make sure incision doesn't show if you've wearing a scoop or V-neck shirt/ etc. Also make sure the line leading from the port is inserted UNDER your clavicle (my first one, inserted by a radiologist, went OVER the clavicle and not only showed, but occasionally rubbed against clothing. My new port is a Bard Power port, which allows the use of contrast dye (inserted with pressure) for an MRI or CT scan. Now to the most important thing - ask the ons's office for a scrip for EMLA cream. Two hours before you are scheduled for a stick, put a small, pea-sized blob of emla cream (lidocaine derivative) over the port, and cover with a square of sticky saran wrap (the kind that sticks to itself). You will feel absolutely no "ouchies" upon insertion of the port needle!! Best of luck. I know the existence of the port is a constant reminder of why it's there, but it really is very helpful - and will significantly reduce the sticks to the arm/hand.. NOTE: Not all people are licensed or qualified to access a port - so if you're getting blood drawn and want to use your port, be sure to request a qualified nurse (even for scans... sometimes they're referred to as an interventional radiology nurses).

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2007 01:00AM jeanne46 wrote: Hi Bonnie, You seem to have two issues. One is the CEA markers and the other is the pain in your hip. As to CEA markers - some docs use CEA, some use CA15-3 (or CA 27-29) or both - and some oncs don't use markers at all. In cases of metastatic breast cancer, markers are sometimes used to monitor a particular drug therapy, or as a possible indicator of disease progression. Those markers can be reliable and they can also be very unreliable. In my case, I had a normal CEA count, but my CA 15-3 was way up there and my scans showed active disease. If your doc is using the markers, he should also be comparing those to your recent scans (and your upcoming ones). As for the pain in your hip, you should definitely discuss that with your doc and find out what he can do to help make you more comfortable. You didn't mention what your ER/PR and Her2 status is. If you are a triple negative, like I am, then chemo is the only weapon they currently have to fight the cancer. You must be quite a strong lady to have withstood so many years of chemo. Let me know how your MRI scans come out. I hope my information has been helpful. Good luck and take care,

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2012 12:44AM jeanne46 wrote: I'm not sure if there is tylenol in oxycodone. If not, take a whole one.  There is tylenol in hydrocodone.  But you can get hydrocodone (same as Norco or Vicodin) in 5/325 or 10/325 combinations (the number after the backslash represents the mgs. for tylenol).  I think one regular tylenol has 325 mgs. The fentanyl patch comes in various strenths, starting at 12 mcgs. I have found that helpful (but I need a much higher dose).  But if it is too strong, even at the lowest dose, you can always just take it off. Most importantly, try to stay ahead of the pain without taking something that will make it worse in the long run.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2008 11:19AM jeanne46 wrote: Oz, Like the previous posters, I'm also sorry to hear about the progression. And yes, it is always difficult to face. The roller coaster ride isn't a lot of fun. As to ER/PR status - after two years of thinking I was a triple neg, I had a biopsy and it showed I was ER+ (highly). The same tissue was re-examined by a pathologist friend and his report showed only medium ER positivity. Then I had a core biopsy of another spot and it showed an even lower ER+ number. When asked why - I was told that they look at the slide under microscope and sort of eyeball the percentage of ER+ cells in the slide. So, it's not an exact science and seems to depend on which part of the tissue the slide is representative of. With all that said, I was also told that not all ER+ cancers respond to anti-hormonal therapy. I tried two (femara, faslodex) and had some progression on both. Best of luck to you. Hope the xeloda kicks in - they usually give it three cycles before changing. Jeanne

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 05:50PM jeanne46 wrote: Hi Pam, I had a PET/CT that showed possible bone mets (two ribs) and a whole body bone scan that agreed with the first test (also showed soft tissue areas of high contrast uptake). Rib resection confirmed breast ca mets. Your onc can also order some bloodwork to see if there any elevated tumor marker levels that might lead one to suggest further investigation. (Normal levels do not necessarily mean anything and some oncologists don't even use tumor markers). The really good news is that with the PET and bone scans NOTHING else turned up. It could likely be trauma, but if the anxiety is causing great discomfort, then request that your oncologist follow-up now. Sometimes, without any other evidence to the contrary, they prefer to wait a month or two rather than order an invasive biopsy if unnecessary. Other option is to request another radiologist to read the bone scan. Good luck to you and let us know what happens. Wishing you the best possible outcome!

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2010 01:06PM jeanne46 wrote: Have had hot flashes for YEARS after my first bout with breast cancer put me into chemically-induced menopause.  I would be driving down the freeway, at first freezing with the heat on HIGH, then minutes later, sweating so badly the AC was on HIGH.  My friends used to laugh when I went to a movie or theater.  Sweater/jacket on, seater/jacket off, ad nauseum.  I've tried different meds - only Effexor seemed to help - some.  Even tried acupuncture and biofeedback.  Those helped a little too.  I still have the flahses but no where near as frequent or as strong.   Putting something really cold on the top of your head or around your neck can help with flashes (not always convenient to bring these things with you when you're out!).  But I did find that biodfeedback breathing helped minimize the severity.  All in all, flashes are a b...ch.  Just another gift that keeps on giving.

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 03:26PM jeanne46 wrote: Carrie, Sorry you had to find your way here. But this a great place for support, information and sisterhood. I am on the same chemo you will be starting.  Most people find that Navelbine is an easy chemo to take - it does not cause hair loss, rarely causes much nausea, and does not require pre-meds (especially steroids).  Avastin usually doesn't have many SEs, although some ladies have reported some bone pain right after the infusion.  I have not experienced that. Avastin can eventually cause high blood pressure, so they will check your blood pressure regularly (they do anyway). It also can delay healing and cause nosebleeds.  My urine is checked regularly to make sure my kidney function is normal.  You do not want to have a surgery of any kind while on Avastin. My experience with Navelbine was that it was more difficult that I expected.  My white counts got really low and I always required a Neulasta injection and occastionally an injection of Aranesp for red cell counts  I was fatigued and had a lot of stomach acid.  I experienced some weakness in my core muscles (hips and shoulders). That was on a schedule of infusions once a week for three weeks, then one week off.  When my oncologist changed the plan to every other week, the above problems went away. Generally, if you do experience SEs, it occurs during the first few days after your infusion.  For me, having a port has been great.  My veins are very small and hard to find.  The port works well and you can't tell I have it when I'm in clothes (even with a V-neck top). I can also use it for some scans which means less endless sticking to find a good vein. Best of luck to you. Let us know how you are doing.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 08:20PM jeanne46 wrote: I have noticed that my teeth are a little more yellow, especially in the spaces between each tooth. I was only on zometa for about a year before I started to develop osteonecrosis of the jaw. I had to stop zometa treatment. I'm not sure of the technical reason why the jaws (upper and lower) can develop loss of bone density and necrosis while the other bones in the body are being strengthened. A dentist once explained it to me, but chemo brain (last in, first out) has made the info irretrievable! In my case it developed in an area where I had a dental implant put it 3-4 years before I started the bisphosphonate therapy. I am getting a night guard - not only to help with jaw clenching, but also to keep the teeth in place at night (I have a few that are loose due to the bone resorbtion). My dental insurance would only pay for 50% I would definitely recommend a night guard if any of you are grinding at night. The other thing you might consider for the discoloration are the OTC white strips. I also believe that chemo itself can cause discoloration of teeth. I remember the first time I went through chemo years ago my teeth got more yellow. I was not taking any kind of bisphosphonates then. Jeanne

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 01:55PM jeanne46 wrote: So very sorry to hear about your recurrence.  I was 13 1/2 years out before my cancer came back.  Although aggressive to begin with, it was IDC, not IBC.  I know it probably feels like someone just dropped a lead weight on you - but the good news is that it is a local recurrence. Your onc sounds like a gem, watching you so carefully all these years, and ready now to give your errant cells all the big guns. It's not easy recovering from a diagnosis and going right into chemotherapy.  But as many here will tell you, it's doable.  Pamper yourself, let your family and friends wait on you.  Often anti-depressants can be helpful as can psychotherapy and or a local support group (check with your onc's office or the local ACS chapter for referrals).  And avail yourself of all the information from the knowledgeable ladies on these boards. Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2008 11:21AM jeanne46 wrote: A lot of how your mom will react to her chemo regime depends on what chemo she is being given? Usually there is a low point in the cycle when the body's defenses are least able to fight infection (white and/or red blood cell counts are at their lowest points). I travel while on chemo - just try to arrange my trips so they coincide with my off weeks. In fact, I know lots of women who travel while on chemo. Best to discuss this issue with your Mom's oncologist. Since your Mom is starting next week, see how she does. We each respond to a given treatment in many different ways. How your fiance's mother reacted and what she was taking may be very different from your Mom's experiences. If your Mom does attend your wedding in Bermuda, you may want to make sure she gets lots of rest if she's tired and save up her energy for the ceremony itself. Congratulations on your upcoming wedding. I do hope your Mom will be able to attend. If not, perhaps you could have another special ceremony at home that she could share with you.
